title: 106_hr671
content: The Transition to Adulthood Program Act of 1999, also known as the Act, focuses on the transition of foster children to self-sufficiency. The Transition to Adulthood Program Act of 1999 focuses on enabling foster children to achieve self-sufficiency by providing foster care maintenance payments for those under 21 years old who are completing education, enrolled in postsecondary institutions or vocational training, or employed for at least 80 hours per month, with a case plan for independent living. The Transition to Adulthood Program Act of 1999 aims to support foster children in achieving self-sufficiency through foster care maintenance payments for those under 21 years old who are pursuing education, vocational training, or employment. The Act also includes provisions for nonresidential services to assist in the transition to independent adult living, such as programs promoting education, training, or employment. The amendments made by this Act will take effect on October 1, 1999. SEC. 3. Qualified former foster care recipients established as a targeted group for computing the work opportunity credit for employment of certain new employees. Qualified former foster care recipients are now included as a targeted group for the work opportunity credit under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. An individual aged 18 to 25 certified by a designated agency qualifies as a "qualified former foster care recipient." Individuals aged 18 to 25 who were former foster care recipients are now eligible for the work opportunity credit under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The amendments made by this section apply to individuals who start working for the employer after December 31, 1999. SEC. 4 amends the Social Security Act to increase the allowable assets for children in foster care. Children with combined resources valued at $10,000 or less will be considered to have resources valued at $1,000 or less. SEC. 5 focuses on interagency collaboration to promote self-sufficiency for children aging out of foster care. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will establish an action plan to promote collaboration between different federal agencies to support the self-sufficiency of children aging out of foster care. Additionally, there will be an update to the funding formula for the Foster Care Independent Living Initiatives Program. The funding formula for the Foster Care Independent Living Initiatives Program will be updated to reflect the average number of children in foster care in 1996. Additionally, there will be a funding increase for states based on specific ratios. The term 'basic ceiling' is defined as $58,000,000 for fiscal year 2000 and each subsequent year. A hold harmless provision is amended to ensure states receive a minimum funding amount for foster care programs. The amendments made by this section will be effective on October 1, 1999, impacting the total amount required to be paid to the State under this paragraph for fiscal year 1999.
